website_summaries.verdict: A good book for beginners in graphic design that explains the primary principles of design.
pros: Uses visual examples and easy-to-understand text to explain scale, point, line, hierarchy, layers, typography, and designing with color
Ideal for beginners looking for an introduction to these concepts
cons: Some topics could be discussed in more detail
This is not a book meant for experienced designers

customer_reviews.title: A reference manual, not a tutorial.
customer_reviews.text: This book is not a tutorial on learning graphic design. It is more like a reference book for someone who has been trained in graphic design. One more note about this book, is the elements that are shared in it, can be learned from composition for drawing or paiting. However, I have not read the entire book yet, but have gotten through 25% of it. What I was looking for was a tutorial, a book to train me in graphic design. What I found was a reference manual. As a reference manual, it is very good with excellent picture examples.
customer_reviews.author: C. W. J

customer_reviews.title: Great for beginners!
customer_reviews.text: I bought this book because other reviews said it was required for a college class and I wanted to get a taste for what formal instruction of graphic design entails. This book did exactly that, breaking design down into separate aspects of art and showing lots of examples of it. It helps with getting comfortable with design "lingo" too. A great introduction for people who don't want to spend thousands on college courses.
customer_reviews.author: Lisa Markle

customer_reviews.title: Great book
customer_reviews.text: Truth is I don't like to read. I used to study graphic design during my communication studies -and it was just plain text books. I never understood how I was supposed to understand design from plain text books. This book is visually enthusing and it was a pleasure going trough it. They have some really great pointers in the book. And they really designed the book very well.
customer_reviews.author: Kristine

customer_reviews.title: Pretty, not substantial
customer_reviews.text: Really just a picture book, no instruction or process explanation. Pretty sure the basics listed have always been the basics, so not sure why called "New Basics." If you want a pretty coffee table book, buy it. If you wanted graphic design guidance, buy something else.
customer_reviews.author: Melissa G

customer_reviews.title: Trite
customer_reviews.text: This isn’t even a reference book for design it reads more as a brief introduction to contemporary art. Meaning lots of uninteresting deadpan photos and very little actual knowledge of design is shared. Oh be had this book for a day and read it entirely within an hour. There is no reason to keep this book now since I already own enough reference books with far more inspiring and less obtuse work.
customer_reviews.author: Justin Miller

customer_reviews.title: Good introduction to the basic concepts of contemporary design
customer_reviews.text: This is a very good introduction to many of the basic concepts of contemporary design. Each section (be it texture, hierarchy, color, rhythm and balance,...) is a relatively short overview of the concept, followed by many diverse and well crafted examples to compare and contrast. If you're looking for an general design book to start with, this one is pretty solid. From this you can figure out what topics you want to launch into more in depth. Maybe Gestalt principles are inspiring you. Or possibly the Grid.
customer_reviews.author: D. Morris

customer_reviews.title: An effective introduction to the essential elements of graphic design
customer_reviews.text: Graphic Design The New Basics by Ellen Lupton and Jennifer Cole Phillips is an effective introduction to the essential elements of graphic design. Each chapter is dedicated to one of these elements, such as rhythm and balance, color, scale, hierarchy, and the like. Their explanations are easy to understand but the strength of the book lies in the numerous examples they provide. Explaining the concepts is one thing but having vivid and various examples certainly reinforces the ideas.
customer_reviews.author: Tom Ipri

customer_reviews.title: Best intro book ever.
customer_reviews.text: This book is wonderful. I use it as a guide to teach my students the foundations of design. There are many wonderful projects and visual inspirations included. It is a great balance of text an image and makes for light reading that is impactful and to the point, and provides a range of projects, concepts, and visuals related to each topic. An absolute must for the bookshelf of a young designer and just as wonderful as refreshing inspiration for a seasoned vet!
customer_reviews.author: Casey Kelly

customer_reviews.title: Picture Book, Behance
customer_reviews.text: This book doesn't offer any helpful instruction on the basics of design. This is my second book by the same author and Ellen just seems more interested in impressing the reader with complex vocabulary and a confusing mastery of design. Very little content, and you can find more helpful/inspiring design on Behance. This book feels like a cash grab by just printing others work and throwing in some nonsensical text along with it. It gets two stars for presentation, but that's it.
customer_reviews.author: Bobby S.

customer_reviews.title: Love this book
customer_reviews.text: If you need to learn the basics of Two-Dimensional Design theory and see it applied in the world. This is the bomb.
